awd_titl_txt: Investigating the Use of Peer Role Models to Inspire Women to Thrive in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal was submitted in response to EHR Core Research (ECR) program announcement NSF 15-509.  As part of ECR, this project is funded by the Research on Gender in Science and Engineering (GSE) program. GSE seeks to understand and address gender-based differences in STEM education and workforce participation through education and implementation research that will lead to a larger and more diverse domestic STEM workforce. Stereotype threat and feelings of not belonging are suggested as important contributors of the under-achievement and underrepresentation of women in STEM. Numerous past laboratory experiments have shown that math-talented peer female role models alleviate the negative effect of stereotype threat, which should then foster feelings of belongingness in STEM. The key mechanism underlying the beneficial effect of peer role models seems to be gender similarity. This research study will engage in an in-depth exploration of similarity in order to build understanding of the peer role model effect and identify ways to make peer role models optimally effective.

This project will provide a rich amount of lab-based and prospective, real-world data that will advance theory and knowledge on ways peer role models can inspire women to thrive and persist in STEM. Experiments will investigate the impact of increasing similarity between women and peer role models, examine whether substituting one source of similarity with another can turn male peers into role models, and attempt to identify the source or combination of sources of similarity that optimize the peer role model effect. The research will be conducted at San Diego State University (SDSU) and the knowledge gained from this research will then be used to inform a prospective field study conducted in San Diego high school math classrooms. High school is a time when mathematics-related gender differences begin to emerge and these gender differences seem to be strong predictors of women's choice to pursue and persist in STEM. This is also a time when peer influence is particularly strong. Hence, introducing peer role models into high school math classrooms would be a particularly beneficial method for reducing the gender gap in STEM.

por.por_cntn:
Our project examined peer role model (PRM) similarity and its effect on women and Latinx college and high school students' science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) participation and persistence. PRMs are slightly older students who are viewed as similar to fellow students (e.g., based on shared attributes), and are perceived to be competent and/or successful in a relevant academic domain (e.g., STEM). Given that women and Latinx students are often perceived as lacking the ability to succeed in STEM fields we reasoned that exposure to PRMs could act as a buffer against these negative perceptions because PRMs are a readily available and clear demonstration of someone like them (i.e., similar) who has thrived in STEM and hence, may empower these students to think that, ?we can do it too?. Our focus on PRM similarity was borne out of the proposition that when students see adequate numeric representation of similar, successful others in a given environment (e.g., a classroom) it could provide a powerful social signal that people who ?look like them? do fit or are welcome in that environment. Perceived similarity is typically based on salient attributes such as shared race and/or gender. The current research moved beyond examining these typical sources of source of similarity to a broader focus on how multiple or different sources of similarity with PRMs could influence PRM effectiveness.

Laboratory work directly examined those attributes that increase PRM similarity by focusing on whether adding to the number of similar attributes (e.g., shared gender, race, cultural background) enhances PRM effectiveness and whether one source of similarity (e.g., cultural background) could compensate for a lack of another source of similarity (e.g., different gender). We further explored if similarity can be based on shared race or gender then might a more personally relevant attribute be an even more powerful way to create a sense of similarity with PRMs. One such attribute could be the cultural experiences that are unique to a given ethnic group. For Latinx students in STEM, that cultural experience may center on the challenges of juggling their strong family values (e.g., taking part in family activities and giving back to the family) with the rigors of academic work (e.g., being a good student). Findings from our research demonstrated that when highlighting Latinx PRMs? struggles as well as their desires to fulfill this family-school balance it increased both male and female Latinx students? similarity perceptions and likewise furthered their interest in pursuing STEM. Some of this research has been published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at research conferences:

Marx, D. M. (2020). Cultural connections: Culturally matched female peer role models boost students? STEM interest. In S. J. Ko & D. Marx (Co-Chairs), A cultural education: Attending to culture improves underrepresented students? academic experiences. Symposium conducted at the meeting of the Western Psychological Association, San Francisco, CA.

Marx, D. M. (2019). Fear of the known?: The effect of peer relevance and gender on women?s math performance under threat. Social Psychology of Education, 22, 1197-1214.

Field work in college foundational math classes (e.g., calculus) revealed that PRM exposure positively impacted students? sense of belonging and their belief that they have the ability to succeed in STEM. These benefits occurred among not only high math-identified female students, but also among low-math identified Latino students. PRM exposure also boosted students' STEM persistence as measured by repeating the same class or continuing in the math sequence. Studies in high school math classes demonstrated that Latinx PRM exposure addressed different sociocultural factors that limited STEM participation and persistence depending on the group to which the student belonged. When considering intersecting identities of sex and ethnicity, PRMs were particularly beneficial for Latina students? STEM intentions. This finding is especially encouraging because increasing STEM participation among ?double STEM minorities?, such as Latinas, is particularly critical given their lack of STEM representation in college. Some of this research has been published in the following peer-reviewed journals:

Ko, S. J., Marx, D. M., Nickerson, S. D., & Bjorkman, K. (2019). Implementing a peer role model program in college calculus classes to broaden women?s participation in STEM. PRIMUS: Problems, Resources, and Issues in Mathematics Undergraduate Studies, 30, 349-366.

Ko, S. J., & Marx, D. M. (2019). Assessing high school students? cost concerns about pursuing STEM: ?Is it worth it??. Hispanic Journal of Behavioral Sciences, 41, 29-41.
